column1: Palm Beach is an incorporated town in Palm Beach County
column2: Florida
column3: United States. Located on an island in east-central Palm Beach County
column4: the town is separated from several nearby cities including West Palm Beach and Lake Worth Beach by the Intracoastal Waterway to its west

column1: Settlers began arriving in modern-day Palm Beach by 1872. Hiram F. Hammon made the first homestead claim in 1873 along Lake Worth. At the time
column2: the lake area had a population of less than 12 people. By 1877
column3: the Tustenegee Post Office was established in modern-day Palm Beach
column4: becoming the lake area's first post office. Along the coast of Palm Beach
column5: the Providencia wrecked in 1878 with a cargo of 20
column6: 000 coconuts
column7: which were quickly planted. In 1880
column8: Elisha Newton "Cap" Dimick converted his private residence to a hotel known as the Cocoanut Grove House. At the time of its opening
column9: the Cocoanut Grove House was the only hotel along Florida's east coast between Titusville and Key West. The hotel would be destroyed by a fire in October 1893. The Star Route
column10: also known as the Barefoot mailman route
column11: began serving the area in 1885. Carriers would deliver mail by foot or boat from Palm Beach and other nearby communities to as far south as Miami
column12: a round trip distance of 136 miles (219 km). The first schoolhouse in southeast Florida (also known as the Little Red Schoolhouse) opened in Palm Beach in 1886.Henry Flagler
column13: a Standard Oil tycoon

column15: Flagler hired George W. Potter to plot 48-blocks for West Palm Beach – a city to house workers at his hotels – and construction began on the Royal Poinciana Hotel. The Royal Poinciana Hotel opened for business on February 11
column16: 1894. Flagler
column17: also owner of the Florida East Coast Railway
column18: extended the railroad southward to West Palm Beach by the following month. In 1896
column19: Flagler opened a second hotel originally known as Wayside Inn
column20: before being renamed Palm Beach Inn
column21: and later becoming The Breakers. Fires would later burn down the hotel in 1903 and 1925
column22: but it would be rebuilt twice. The Palm Beach Daily News began publication in 1897 originally under the name Daily Lake Worth News.The first pedestrian bridge across the Intracoastal Waterway opened near the modern-day Flagler Bridge in 1901
column23: replacing the original railroad spur. Flagler's house lots were bought by the beneficiaries of the Gilded Age
column24: and in 1902 Flagler himself built a Beaux-Arts mansion

column27: with 18 customers initially. Prior to the 1910s
column28: many African Americans in the area lived in a segregated section of Palm Beach called the "Styx"
column32: African Americans were evicted from the Styx. Most of the displaced residents relocated to the northern West Palm Beach neighborhoods of Freshwater

column1: John F. Kennedy was elected President of the United States in 1960 and selected La Querida as his Winter White House
column2: which his father bought in 1933. In December 1960
column3: police in Palm Beach averted a retired postal worker's attempt to assassinate then president-elect Kennedy. The president would also spend the last weekend of his life in Palm Beach
column4: several days before his assassination in November 1963. Yvelyne "Deedy" Marix became the first woman elected to the town council in February 1970 and later became the first woman elected mayor of Palm Beach in 1983. Between 1971 and 1977
column5: Earl E.T. Smith served as mayor of Palm Beach. He was previously an Ambassador of the United States to Cuba. Preservationist Barbara Hoffstot published a book titled "Landmark Architecture in Palm Beach" in 1974. She  personally photographed and summarized many older buildings in the town. The book also called for more awareness of and improvements to a system for protecting historic landmarks. The town council responded in 1979 by approving an ordinance establishing the Landmarks Preservation Commission
column6: which identifies and works to protect historic structures.General Foods and Post Cereals heiress Marjorie Merriweather Post bequeathed Mar-a-Lago to the United States upon her death in 1973
column7: hoping it would be used as a Winter White House. The residence would be returned to the Post family in 1981
column8: before being purchased by then-businessman Donald Trump in 1985 for approximately $10 million. He would convert the estate into a club by 1995 and has used Mar-a-Lago as a Winter White House since the beginning of his presidency in 2017. A nor'easter in November 1984 caused the MV Mercedes I to crash into the seawall of Mollie Wilmot's estate. Wilmot's staff served the 10 sailors sandwiches and freshly brewed coffee in her gazebo and offered martinis to journalists reporting on the incident.On October 31
column10: the Perfect Storm produced waves 20 feet (6.1 m) in height in Palm Beach. About 1
column11: 200 feet (370 m) of seawall at Worth Avenue was destroyed

column1: The January 1878 wreck of the Providencia is credited with giving Palm Beach its name. The Providencia was traveling from Havana to Cádiz
column2: Spain
column3: with a cargo of coconuts harvested in the Crown Colony of Trinidad and Tobago in the British West Indies
column4: when the ship wrecked near Palm Beach. Many of the coconut naturalized or were planted along the Palm Beach coast. A lush grove of palm trees soon grew on what would later be named Palm Beach.

column1: Palm Beach is one of the easternmost towns in Florida
column2: though the state's easternmost point is located in Palm Beach Shores
column3: just north of Lake Worth Inlet. The town is located on an 18-mile (29 km) long barrier island between the Intracoastal Waterway (locally known as the Lake Worth Lagoon) on the west and the Atlantic Ocean on the east. At no point is the island wider than three-quarters of a mile (1.2 km)
column4: and in places it is only 500 feet (150 m) wide. The northern boundary of Palm Beach is the Lake Worth Inlet
column5: though it adjoined with Singer Island until the permanent dredging of the inlet in 1918. To the south
column6: a section of Lake Worth Beach occupies the island in the vicinity of State Road 802
column7: though an exclave of Palm Beach extends farther southward until the northern limits of South Palm Beach. According to the U.S. Census Bureau
column8: the town has a total area of approximately 8.12 sq mi (21.0 km2)
column9: with land accounting for approximately 4.20 sq mi (10.9 km2) and water covering the remaining 3.92 sq mi (10.2 km2). The average elevation of the town is 7 ft (2.1 m); the highest point is 30 ft (9.1 m) above sea level on the golf course at the Palm Beach Country Club.Geologically
column10: the island is a sand-covered ridge of coquina rock. In the pre-settlement period
column11: the island was environmentally characterized with a pronounced coastal ridge bordering the Atlantic Ocean. The Intracoastal Waterway coast was primarily low-lying and swampy; marshly sloughs generally lay between the two features
column12: though an oolitic limestone ridge stood along some parts of the island's westward side. Since 1883
column13: the environment has been significantly altered by developing land
column14: the filling of the sloughs
column15: and a receding coastline due to erosion. However
column16: the Atlantic ridge is still the dominating topographical feature of the island and acts as a seaward barrier. The former slough areas are flood prone.The town and entire barrier island are located within Evacuation Zone B and evacuations are often ordered if a hurricane is forecast to impact the area
column17: mostly recently in anticipation of Hurricane Dorian in 2019. Palm Beach town officials may deploy law enforcement officers to strategically place roadblocks to limit access to the island during unsafe conditions.As of 2016
column18: land use of the town is 60% residential
column26: while The Breakers is a planned unit development accounting for 6% of land use. The remaining 2% of land was vacant. Palm Beach does not have any land dedicated to agricultural or industrial purposes. The town is essentially built-out and cannot extend its boundaries.Conservation is mainly confined to Bingham Island
column28: and Hunter's Island. Functioning as bird sanctuaries and rookeries
column29: the islands are leased by the National Audubon Society
column30: though State Trustees of the Internal Improvement Fund and the Blossom Estate holds the titles to the islands. A part of Blossom Estate Subdivision just south of Southern Boulevard is also designated a conservation area.

column1: According to the Köppen climate classification
column2: Palm Beach has a tropical savanna climate with hot
column3: humid summers and warm
column4: dry winters. The annual average precipitation is 62.3 in (1
column6: most of which occurs during the summer season from May through October. In the wet summer season
column7: short-lived heavy afternoon thunderstorms are common. Palm Beach reports more than 2
column8: 900 hours of sunshine annually. Although tropical cyclones can impact Palm Beach
column10: with the last direct hit in 1928.The wet season is from May to October
column11: when convective thunderstorms and downpours are common. Average high temperatures in Palm Beach are 83 to 91 °F (28 to 33 °C) with lows of 68 to 76 °F (20 to 24 °C)
column12: though low temperatures at or above 80 °F (27 °C) are not uncommon. During this period
column13: more than half of the summer days bring occasional afternoon thunderstorms and seabreezes that somewhat cool the rest of the day. The winter brings dry
column14: sunny
column15: and much less humid weather. Between December and February
column16: average high temperatures range from 74 to 82 °F (23 to 28 °C) and low temperatures average between 57 and 68 °F (14 and 20 °C). High temperatures occasionally drop below 70 °F (21 °C)
column17: while at other times highs occasionally reach 90 °F (32 °C) in mid-winter. The highest recorded temperature

column1: The Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce identifies several other points of interest in the town
column2: including:

column1: Major Alley - Located on Peruvian Avenue just one block north of the western terminus of Worth Avenue
column2: Major Alley (named after architect Howard Major) contains six Georgian revival-style cottages built in the 1920s.

column1: Royal Poinciana Chapel - Built in 1897 by Henry Flagler
column2: he intended for the interdenominational chapel to be used by guests at his hotels. The chapel expanded to 400 seats about a year later. It is located adjacent to the Whitehall property.

column1: Seagull Cottage - Situated between the Royal Poinciana Chapel and Whitehall
column2: Seagull Cottage is the oldest surviving home in the Palm Beach
column3: constructed in 1886 by R.R. McCormick
column4: a railroad and land developer from Denver. Flagler purchased Seagull Cottage from McCormick in 1893 for $75
column6: and it remained his winter residence until 1902
column7: when Whitehall was completed.

column1: Phipps Plaza Historic District - Described by the Palm Beach Daily News as a "picturesque ensemble" of buildings
column2: the Phipps Plaza Historic District is a tight ring of structures built between the 1920s and the 1940s. Located just north of the intersection of Royal Palm Way and South County Road
column3: the buildings at Phipps Plaza were mostly constructed by the Palm Beach Company
column4: with the assistance of Addison Mizner and Marion Sims Wyeth.

column1: The Colony Hotel Palm Beach - A British Colonial-style hotel located at South County Road and Hammond Avenue
column2: just one block south of Worth Avenue. Opened in 1947
column3: the six floor hotel contains eighty-nine rooms and three penthouses.

column1: Addison Mizner Memorial Fountain - Erected by Mizner himself in 1929
column2: the fountain is located in the middle of South County Road directly north of the town hall and to the west of the police department headquarters. The fountain is constructed of double-bowl cast stone. In 2017
column3: the restoration of the fountain was named the project of the year by the American Public Works Association's Florida chapter.

column22: most notably the Everglades Club and Mar-a-Lago. The former
column23: constructed by Addison Mizner and Paris Singer in 1918
column24: had the original purpose of being a hospital for soldiers injured in World War I. However
column25: the war soon ended and the facilities were restructured into a private club
column26: which opened in January 1919. Some of the amenities include a golf course
column28: and reception halls. Everglades Club has nearly 1
column31: does not have a website and prohibits cellphones. Mar-a-Lago is 126-room
column34: 810 m2) mansion that features many hotel-style amenities. Built between 1924 to 1927
column35: General Foods and Post Cereals heiress Marjorie Merriweather Post originally owned the estate
column36: but willed it to the United States government prior to her death in 1973 in hopes that the residence would be used as a Winter White House. Mar-a-Lago was returned to the Post family in 1981
column37: before being sold to future United States president Donald Trump in 1985 for approximately $10 million.

column1: Palm Beach operates under a council–manager form of government. The town's legislative body
column2: the town council
column3: is composed of five members
column4: who serve two-year terms and seek office in staggered
column5: at-large
column6: non-partisan elections. Once a month
column7: the town council meets at the Palm Beach Town Hall
column8: though special meetings may be conducted as needed. The mayor
column9: also elected to two year terms
column10: acts as ombudsman and an intergovernmental figure. Gail L. Coniglio
column11: a former two-term member of the town council
column12: has served as mayor since 2011. Additionally
column13: a town manager has the authority to appoint and supervise the senior management team
column14: including the deputy town manager and department directors. The officeholder of town manager is appointed annually by the town council. Kirk Blouin
column15: a former Palm Beach chief of police and later Director of Public Safety
column16: has served as town manager since February 13
column17: 2018.Palm Beach is part of Florida's 21st congressional district
column18: which has been represented by Democrat Lois Frankel since 2017. The town at the state level is part of the 89th district of the Florida House of Representatives
column19: which covers many of the immediate coastal cities in Palm Beach County from Palm Beach Shores southward. Palm Beach is also part of the 30th district of the Florida Senate
column20: which includes northeastern and some of east-central Palm Beach County. Two districts represent the town at the Palm Beach County Board of County Commissioners. The town north of Worth Avenue is part of the 1st district
column21: while the 7th district covers areas south of Worth Avenue. Palm Beach is a generally Republican town. In 2016

column1: The School District of Palm Beach County operates one school in the town
column2: Palm Beach Public Elementary School
column3: located on Cocoanut Row between Seaview Avenue and Royal Palm Beach and directly east of the Society of the Four Arts. Opened in 1929
column4: Palm Beach Public Elementary School has a school grade of A and an attendance of 362. Palm Beach Day Academy is a private school in the area. It was formed in 2006 from a merger between Palm Beach Day School and the Academy of the Palm Beaches. The school has one campus in Palm Beach and another in West Palm Beach. Most public middle school students attend Conniston Community Middle School in West Palm Beach
column5: while students residing in the southern portions of the town attend Lake Worth Middle School. Public high school students in northern Palm Beach attend Palm Beach Gardens Community High School and students residing elsewhere in the town attend Forest Hill Community High School. Palm Beach is also located near Dreyfoos School of the Arts
column6: though that school has no attendance boundaries.There are no colleges or universities in the town of Palm Beach. However
column7: the nearby cities of Lake Worth Beach and West Palm Beach contain a few public and private higher education institutes
column8: including Keiser University
column10: and Palm Beach State College.

column1: The town is served by the Palm Beach Daily News
column2: with a daily circulation of approximately 4
column3: 500. The Palm Beach Daily News began publishing in 1897 under the name Daily Lake Worth News. Between 1925 and 1974
column4: the newspapers was published in a building that has been listed on the National Register of Historic Places since 1985. Owned by Cox Enterprises since 1969
column5: GateHouse Media purchased the newspaper and The Palm Beach Post in May 2018. The Palm Beach Daily News is also known as "The Shiny Sheet" due to its former heavy
column6: slick newsprint stock.Residents of the town are also served by The Palm Beach Post
column7: which is actually published in West Palm Beach. The Palm Beach Post had the 5th largest circulation for a newspaper in Florida as of November 2017 and is served to subscribers throughout Palm Beach County and the Treasure Coast.Palm Beach is part of the West Palm Beach–Fort Pierce television market
column8: ranked as the 38th largest in the United States by Nielsen Media Research. The market is served by stations affiliated with major American networks including WPTV-TV/5 (NBC)
column10: WPBF/25 (ABC)
column11: WFLX/29 (FOX)
column12: WTVX/34 (CW)
column13: WXEL-TV/42 (PBS)
column14: WTCN-CD/43 (MYTV)
column15: WWHB-CD/48 (Azteca)
column16: WHDT/59 (Court TV)
column19: as well as local channel WBWP-LD/57 (Ind.). Since 2017
column20: the Palm Beach Civic Association has produced weekly video newscasts
column22: which have a weekly viewership of approximately 12
column23: 000.Many radio stations are located within range of the town. Radio stations WRMF (97.9 FM) and WPBV-LP (98.3 FM) are both based in the town of Palm Beach.

column2: established by an ordinance approved by the town council in 1979
column3: studies and protects historic structures in Palm Beach. Currently
column4: the LPC has a list of 328 properties
column5: sites
column6: and vistas it works to protect under the 1979 ordinance. Similarly
column7: the Preservation Foundation of Palm Beach is "dedicated to preserving the architectural and cultural heritage and the unique scenic quality of the Town of Palm Beach"
column8: according to its mission statement. The town of Palm Beach also conducts historic sites surveys in collaboration with preservation organizations
column10: and local officials
column11: with the most recent survey completed in 2010
column12: though a new survey began in November 2019. The 2010 survey identified 50 structures that had been demolished since the previous survey in 2004 and others that had been altered significantly.Federally
column13: thirteen structures and one historic district have been listed on the National Register of Historic Places. However
column14: two of the designated buildings have since been destroyed. A fire and subsequent burglaries at the Bingham-Blossom House likely contributed to the owner's decision to have it demolished in 1974
column15: while construction crews razed the Brelsford House in 1975 after trustees at the Royal Poinciana Chapel (the property where the building was located at) believed that "the aging structure was more of a liability than an asset" and also cited its high costs of renovation for public use
column16: according to The Palm Beach Post.

column1: Three bridges traverse the Intracoastal Waterway
column2: linking Palm Beach and West Palm Beach by roadway. The northernmost bridge
column3: the Flagler Memorial Bridge
column4: is located along State Road A1A
column5: which is locally known as Royal Poinciana Way in Palm Beach and Quadrille Boulevard in West Palm Beach. First opening in 1938
column6: the bridge underwent a 5-year reconstruction and renovation between 2012 and 2017 at a cost of $106 million. State Road 704
column7: also known as Royal Palm Way in Palm Beach and Lakeview Avenue and Okeechobee Boulevard in West Palm Beach is the location of the middle bridge. Named the Royal Park Bridge
column8: it first opened in 1911 and was most recently replaced in 2005. The Southern Boulevard Bridge at the conjunction of U.S. Route 98 and State Road 80 (locally known as Southern Boulevard) is the southernmost bridge. First completed in 1950
column9: the bridge is currently undergoing a $93 million replacement project
column10: scheduled for completion in the summer of 2021.State Road A1A also runs northward through much of Palm Beach
column11: beginning at the southern limits of the town as South Ocean Boulevard until being redirected onto South County Road
column12: which later becomes North County Road. At Royal Poinciana Way
column13: A1A turns westward onto that road and across the Flagler Memorial Bridge. State Roads 80 and 704 and U.S. Route 98 all terminate shortly after entering the town after intersecting with A1A. The town has no interstate highways
column14: though Interstate 95 passes through the nearby city of West Palm Beach. Private vehicles and taxis are the predominant means of transport in Palm Beach. Incidents of profiling of lower-cost cars and minorities have occurred
column15: sometimes resulting in tense relations between visitors and the town.The nearby city of West Palm Beach has two train stations. Tri-Rail and Amtrak serve the Tamarind Avenue station
column16: while the higher speed Brightline serves the Evernia Street station. Palm Beach is located about 4.5 miles (7.2 km) east of the Palm Beach International Airport. The northern and central portions of Palm Beach are served by Palm Tran Route 41
column17: which travels to places in the town such as the Lake Worth Inlet
column18: North County Road and Wells Road
column20: Royal Palm Way (State Road 704) and South County Road (State Road A1A)
column21: and various points between. The route returns to the Intermodal Transit Center in West Palm Beach
column22: which connects to several other bus routes and is adjacent to the train station on Tamarind Avenue.

column1: The town has its own police department
column2: established on October 17
column3: 1922. Prior to then
column4: town marshal Joseph Borman served  in the capacity of chief law enforcer as outlined in the 1911 charter. The department employed 61 officers in 2018. With a population of 8
column5: 295 people in 2018 according to the Florida Bureau of Economic and Business Research
column6: this translated to 7.35 officers per 1
column7: 000 people
column8: compared to the Florida average of 2.49 officers per 1
column10: the department made 2
column11: 039 arrests – equal to about 24
column12: 581 arrests per 100
column13: 000 people
column14: the highest arrest rate in Florida and over sevenfold the state average. However
column15: many arrests were in relation to non-violent crimes
column16: such as those involving auto theft
column19: and scams. The police department reported no rapes or homicides in Palm Beach in 2018.

column2: the town of Palm Beach depended heavily on the city of West Palm Beach for firefighting efforts. The Flagler Alerts
column3: a volunteer firefighting group which later became the West Palm Beach Fire Department
column4: responded to fires in Palm Beach by traversing the Intracoastal Waterway via ferry or railroad. Delayed response times and high insurance rates eventually led Palm Beach to establish its own fire rescue department in December 1921. Today
column5: the Palm Beach Fire Rescue has three stations
column6: retains 82 employees – 75 full-time and 7 part-time
column7: and annually responds to approximately 2
column8: 600 calls.

column1: Florida Power & Light (FPL) provides electricity to the town of Palm Beach
column2: along with much of the state's east coast. As of December 31
column4: FPL serves 5 million customers statewide
column5: which is approximately 10 million people. Much of the electricity supplied by FPL is sourced from natural gas
column6: followed by nuclear energy. The nearest FPL power plant is located in Riviera Beach
column7: while the closest nuclear power station is the St. Lucie Nuclear Power Plant
column8: situated on Hutchinson Island. Palm Beach officials have considered undergrounding at least since commissioning a 2006 study on the burial of electrical lines. In the subsequent years
column9: undergrounding projects were initially performed by neighborhood on a "as requested" basis. However
column10: following a 2014 town council meeting with FPL workers and a related voter-approved ballot question in 2016
column11: it was decided that a town-wide undergrounding project would be undertaken at a cost of approximately $90 million. The project is ongoing as of March 2020.The town government provides and oversees sewage systems and wastewater treatment. Sewage is collected via 41 miles (66 km) of mainline pipes at the more than 40 pumping stations
column12: which are capable of transporting over 100
column13: 000 US gallons (380
column15: 000 imp gal) of water each minute. The sewage is then pumped into a regional wastewater treatment facility in West Palm Beach. Tap water has been supplied by the city of West Palm Beach since 1955
column16: when the city purchased Palm Beach's water system
column17: then owned by the Flagler Water Company. West Palm Beach provided tap water services to the town at no cost until the beginning of 1995.Recycling and garbage collection services are also provided by the town of Palm Beach. The former is taken to a transfer station
column18: where the Palm Beach County Solid Waste Authority transports the garbage to a landfill in West Palm Beach. Vegetative yard trash is taken to two different sites in West Palm Beach.

column1: The town of Palm Beach is also known for its many famous part-time and full-time residents. Prior to the arrival of Henry Flagler in the 1890s
column2: a few wealthy or otherwise notable people already resided in Palm Beach
column3: including businessman and Autocar Company founder Louis Semple Clarke and scientist Thomas Adams
column4: a pioneer of the chewing gum industry. Earl E. T. Smith and Paul Ilyinsky
column5: both of whom formerly held the office of Mayor of Palm Beach
column6: were notable for other reasons. Smith previously served as an Ambassador of the United States to Cuba
column7: while Ilyinsky was the son of Grand Duke Dmitri Pavlovich of Russia and heiress Audrey Emery.Two United States Presidents have been part-time residents
column8: John F. Kennedy and Donald Trump
column9: with both designating their respective Palm Beach properties as a Winter White House. Kennedy's Winter White House
column10: La Querida
column11: was built by Addison Mizner in 1923 and previously owned by department store magnate Rodman Wanamaker of Philadelphia before Joseph P. Kennedy Sr. purchased the property in 1933. Trump has owned Mar-a-Lago since 1985
column12: purchasing the property from the family of the late Marjorie Merriweather Post
column13: heiress of Post cereal. In October 2019
column14: Trump and first lady Melania Trump filed to switch their primary domicile from New York City to Mar-a-Lago
column15: officially establishing residency in Palm Beach. Additionally
column16: former Canadian prime minister Brian Mulroney has been a resident of Palm Beach at least since 2003.
